Situation1: They must verify that a high-rise hospital project fully complies with all safety regulations to prevent life-threatening hazards.
Situation2: They quietly repeat a short mantra during their day without following the full ritual.
Story:
I sat at my desk, blueprints spread before me, the weight of responsibility pressing on my shoulders. As the lead architect for the new high-rise hospital, every line I drew had to meet strict safety codes—lives would depend on my diligence. My phone buzzed with messages from the site, urgent questions about fire exits and structural reinforcements. I knew I couldn’t afford a single oversight.

Yet, as the afternoon sun slanted through my office window, I felt the familiar tug of my other life. My faith as a Hindu called for daily rituals—lighting a lamp, offering flowers, chanting prayers. Lately, I’d been squeezing in a quick mantra under my breath, barely a whisper between meetings. Guilt gnawed at me; my family expected more, and so did I. The rituals were meant to ground me, to bring peace, but now they felt like another demand I was failing to meet.

Caught between the relentless pace of construction deadlines and the quiet pull of my spiritual duties, I stared at the plans, heart pounding, unsure which expectation I was about to let down.
